channel.title: Lost on as to why this is not working
channel.description:
Don't understand why this won't work, any help?
[IMG]http://i62.tinypic.com/2w3xjev.jpg[/img]
Also, sorry if it's a bit large.

item.title: Lost on as to why this is not working
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Limits, post:7, topic:552287”][quote author=t4 link=topic=671204.msg4488707#msg4488707 date=1435991143]

i’m not sure what string is, but since this is C as other have stated equals (==) is not overloaded. in order for me to tell you how to compare the strings I would need to see the source code for whatever the type string is.

Can’t you just compare the ASCIII values of each char in the string

The type string doesn’t exist in C, it’s either probably:

or

[/quote]
I’m not sure if C has it, but I know C++ has a string object that is included in the standard lib or whatever it is called.[/quote]

C is not object oriented, so it has no objects. Everything in C is based on manipulating raw memory and every data type of the language is meant to ease that process. Strings are usually stored in 2 ways, either as a length and an array of characters, or as an array of characters with a terminator (usually null/0). The C standard library expects the latter definition, where you sacrifice an extra character in the string and do not store any sort of length. This has many advantages and disadvantages, but it is a compact form and does not require passing a struct around, similar to what you would think of as an object in OOP languages.

Read full topic
item.source: Lost on as to why this is not working

item.title: Lost on as to why this is not working
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

strings are character arrays in C, unless you have some sort of fancy struct wrapper like glib.

Read full topic

@justaguy wrote:

[quote=“Limits, post:7, topic:552287”][quote author=t4 link=topic=671204.msg4488707#msg4488707 date=1435991143]

i’m not sure what string is, but since this is C as other have stated equals (==) is not overloaded. in order for me to tell you how to compare the strings I would need to see the source code for whatever the type string is.

Can’t you just compare the ASCIII values of each char in the string

The type string doesn’t exist in C, it’s either probably:

or

[/quote]
I’m not sure if C has it, but I know C++ has a string object that is included in the standard lib or whatever it is called.[/quote]

C does not have such a standard library, just a library with some string functions.

item.title: Lost on as to why this is not working
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

quote=“Pure_, post:2, topic:552287” == (String) doesn’t compare the value of the strings, try using strcmp
edit: In the future screenshot and upload to imgur or push your code to pastebin with its output.[/quote]Note that this is only the case for C, since there’s no standard for operator overloading. This works fine in C++ using stl strings and not whatever strings you’re using.

Read full topic
item.source: Lost on as to why this is not working

item.title: Lost on as to why this is not working
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

(String) == (String) doesn’t compare the value of the strings, try using strcmp
edit: In the future screenshot and upload to imgur or push your code to pastebin with its output.

Read full topic
